fr:mainmatter.fr:p: I'm a recent graduate in computer science from the Singapore University of Technology and Design, good for backend development, software infrastructure and low-level computing.

I have a special interest in studying and improving technical collaboration tools: Tools for easily expressing and compositing ideas in precise and useful ways, and to repair or maintain those ideas sensibly over time as new requirements arise. This covers a surprisingly wide range of tools which I feel share the same underlying backbone: Everything from casual productivity and collaboration apps, to open-source software development platforms, to programming and specification language theory, to interactive theorem proving, proof repair and logic. I think these topics should be seen holistically from both a human linguistics, as well as a mathematical standpoint.
I had the opportunity to explore these topics first as an open-source Rust crate maintainer, and then in my thesis where I developed a reliance check for infrastructure-as-code (Ansible Playbooks).
In my free time, apart from my above interests, I enjoy creative writing, linguistics, worldbuilding and writing cat haikus in broken Japanese.

I did a concurrent BEng in computer science and MSc in tech entrepreneurship at SUTD, Singapore. My thesis was for my MSc; I managed to wangle my way into doing a programming language theory thesis out of interest.

fr:mainmatter.fr:strong: If you're skimming my profile for relevant stuff, you can stop here; thanks so much for reading! The rest of my (more informal) blog is here.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: This is an informal blog! For my profile with more relevant stuff, click here.
Here's where I plan to dump my various thoughts on programming languages, human linguistics and some creative writing. These might not be very complete nor sound.

This website is written using a really nice tool called forester. It's essentially a collection of notes (a "forest") in a relatively freeform format; some are self-contained and some are organized into series. Apart from clicking links, you can press Ctrl+K to search if you somehow know what you're looking for.
